column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=They make an excellent fire— bright,
#Text=clear, and free from blaze, and particularly suited for
#Text=broiling, and for burning refuse.
#Text=One of the difficulties associated with the burning of refuse is that
#Text=servants say they cannot dispose of it thus because
#Text=it makes a bad smell.
#Text=If, however, the mistress
#Text=will insist upon having it burnt in small quantities
#Text=at a time, as it is produced, have it put on the fire
#Text=when the latter is low, but before it gets dull, and
#Text=then covered with cinders and a little damp coaldust, and it will burn away without causing any bad
#Text=smell.
#Text=It is when rubbish is allowed to accumulate, and when the attempt is made to burn a
#Text=quantity at once, that the fire goes out, and
#Text=an unpleasant odour is created.
#Text=With a little
#Text=management, everything that cannot bo used may
#Text=be burnt either at the copper fire or the kitchen
#Text=fire — bones (broken up), tea-leaves, fragments, and
#Text=everything else ; and as a result, instead of bad
#Text=smells being produced, they will be avoided ; because damp refuse put into a dust-bin very speedily
#Text=ferments or decomposes, and causes a smell which
#Text=is dangerous as welt as unpleasant, and is the cause
#Text=of cholera and typhoid ; while refuse burnt is rendered quite harmless.
